<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 234, 293]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 243, 318]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 303, 907, 318]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 344]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 216, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 696, 732, 728]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
Particles \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{kg}\) and \(Q\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) are free to move on a smooth horizontal plane. \(P\) is projected at a speed of \(2 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) towards \(Q\) which is stationary. After the collision \(P\) and \(Q\) move in opposite directions with speeds of \(0.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) and \(1 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 185, 154]]<|/det|>
<form>Find $m$.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 84, 764, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 305, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
Four coplanar forces of magnitudes \(40 \text{N}, 20 \text{N}, 50 \text{N}\) and \(F \text{N}\) act at a point in the directions shown in the diagram. The four forces are in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 352, 232, 369]]<|/det|>
Find \(F\) and \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 352, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A car starts from rest and moves in a straight line with constant acceleration \(a \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 2}\) for a distance of \(50 \mathrm{~m}\). The car then travels with constant velocity for \(500 \mathrm{~m}\) for a period of \(25 \mathrm{~s}\), before decelerating to rest. The magnitude of this deceleration is \(2a \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 136, 146, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 136, 604, 154]]<|/det|>
Sketch the velocity-time graph for the motion of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 176, 819, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 148, 410]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 392, 316, 410]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 392, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 667, 141, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 551, 685]]<|/det|>
Find the total time for which the car is in motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 667, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
A block \(B\) of mass \(4\mathrm{kg}\) is pushed up a line of greatest slope of a smooth plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal by a force applied to \(B\), acting in the direction of motion of \(B\). The block passes through points \(P\) and \(Q\) with speeds \(12\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) and \(8\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) respectively. \(P\) and \(Q\) are \(10\mathrm{m}\) apart with \(P\) below the level of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 152, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 737, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the decrease in kinetic energy of the block as it moves from \(P\) to \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 361, 143, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
Hence find the work done by the force pushing the block up the slope as the block moves from \(P\) to \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 376, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 853, 92]]<|/det|>
At the instant the block reaches \(Q\), the force pushing the block up the slope is removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 680, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the time taken, after this instant, for the block to return to \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 485, 92]]<|/det|>
The particle comes to instantaneous rest at \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 148, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 336, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(PQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 81, 739, 301]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 320, 920, 402]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(3m \mathrm{kg}\) and \(2m \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley which is attached to the edge of a plane. The plane is inclined at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal. \(A\) lies on the plane and \(B\) hangs vertically, \(0.8 \mathrm{m}\) above the floor, which is horizontal. The string between \(A\) and the pulley is parallel to a line of greatest slope of the plane (see diagram). Initially \(A\) and \(B\) are at rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 414, 146, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 414, 781, 433]]<|/det|>
Given that the plane is smooth, find the value of \(\theta\) for which \(A\) remains at rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 414, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 658, 915, 678]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the plane is rough, \(\theta = 30^{\circ}\) and the acceleration of \(A\) up the plane is \(0.1 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 691, 148, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 691, 707, 710]]<|/det|>
Show that the coefficient of friction between \(A\) and the plane is \(\frac{1}{10}\sqrt{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 691, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 730, 917, 749]]<|/det|>
<form>
